In order to develop a career in the working world its important to know how businesses operate. This unit focuses on business systems and analyses the smooth running of operations across different industries and businesses. 

Learners will: 

Understanding the protocols of systems in business settings
Analyse different operational systems and their effectiveness on business
Understand HR systems and their impact on a business, including tasks such as work appraisals, objective setting, operational planning, scheduling rotas etc.

Sure, here's a sample lesson plan for the topic "HR Systems and their impact on a business":

Subject: Business Systems
Topic: HR Systems and their impact on a business

Aims:

1. To understand the importance of HR systems in business operations
2. To identify different types of systems used in HR and their stakeholders
3. To evaluate the impact of HR systems on the overall performance of a business

Module Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this module, learners will be able to:

1. Define HR systems and their role in business operations
2. Identify different types of HR systems and their stakeholders
3. Analyze the impact of HR systems on business performance

Time Required per Topic:
Topic 1: What are HR Systems? (30 minutes)
Topic 2: Different Types of Systems in HR / Different stakeholders and users in a HR System (60 minutes)
Topic 3: Group Presentations - Evaluating HR System Stakeholders (90 minutes)

Content:

Topic 1: What are HR Systems?

* Definition of HR systems and their role in business operations
* Overview of HR systems' impact on employee management and productivity
* Importance of HR systems in maintaining legal compliance

Topic 2: Different Types of Systems in HR / Different stakeholders and users in a HR System

* Types of HR systems such as Payroll, Performance Management, Recruitment & Selection, Training & Development
* Overview of different stakeholders and users in a HR system such as HR managers, employees, line managers, and external stakeholders
* Discussion of the benefits and challenges associated with each HR system

Topic 3: Group Presentations - Evaluating HR System Stakeholders

* Introduction to group presentations
* Review of different HR systems and their stakeholders
* Instructions for group presentations where learners will create a new HR system for a fictional company
* Evaluation of stakeholder analysis and impact assessment of proposed HR system

Assessment:
Assessment 1: Group Presentation (60%)
Assessment 2: Summary Report and Reflection (40%)

Note: The above lesson plan is just a sample and can be modified based on the needs of the learners and the available resources.

Sure, here's an icebreaker activity for the topic "Definition of HR systems and their role in business operations":

Name Game

1. Ask each learner to introduce themselves by saying their name and their current job title or role.
2. As the facilitator, repeat each learner's name and job title, then add a brief description of an HR system that might be relevant to their role. For example, "Hi John, welcome to the session. You mentioned you're a Business Administrator. In your role, you might be using an HR system for managing employee information such as their personal details and employment history."
3. Ask each learner to introduce the next person, by repeating their name and the HR system you described for them in step 2.
4. Continue until everyone has been introduced and their role and an HR system relevant to their role have been shared.

This activity is a great way to get to know each other and introduce the topic of HR systems in a fun and engaging way. It also allows learners to think about how HR systems are relevant to their own roles in the workplace.

Sure, here's a shorter icebreaker activity for the same topic:

HR Systems Word Association

1. Ask learners to form a circle.
2. Start by saying a word related to HR systems, such as "employee" or "payroll".
3. The person to your right should then say a word that is associated with the word you just said.
4. Continue around the circle with each person saying a word that is associated with the previous word.
5. If someone can't think of a word, they are out of the game.
6. Keep playing until only one person is left, or until you run out of time.

This activity helps learners to start thinking about the topic of HR systems and gets them engaged and focused on the subject matter.
